articles.title: I have to share this with you guys

articles.author: @fox
articles.description:
recently google put my personal domain into safe browsing blacklist:



today i remembered search console exists, went there, and boy what a fucking lol:



aforementioned crx.php is an entrypoint to my system for self-hosting (mostly my own, and a few forks of) web browser addons for chrome-based browsers outside of their incredibly shitty and poorly-moderated addon store. this leverages GPO on windows and similar knobs on other platforms.
well, naturally, any kind of freedom and american megacorps mix about as well as water and oil, so  something or someone over there got triggered and decided to blacklist (oh oops, should i say denylist? my bad) my website entirely.
all web browsers i‚Äôm aware of have google safe browsing enabled by default.
anyone who reads this should, in my opinion, think about the implications of this.
articles.title: I have to share this with you guys

articles.author: @fox
articles.description:
webracer999:
I don‚Äôt understand what the gitlab CI changes
basically it‚Äôs something that is a lot easier, for me, to deal with. I‚Äôm using CI anyway so it makes sense to use it for binary releases too, that‚Äôs pretty much the gist of it.

 webracer999:
Delete the f-droid repo, if you don‚Äôt maintain it in the future - so it‚Äôs clear for the user
yep.

 webracer999:
What do I have to ‚Äúmigrate‚Äù to the ‚Äúnew‚Äù update method? Do I have to reinstall the app etc.?
no, you won‚Äôt have to reinstall anything, the APK is signed with the same key.
https://gitlab.tt-rss.org/tt-rss/tt-rss-android/-/releases - installing an APK from here should just work.
fixing in-app update notifications to point to gitlab would involve some digging so i can‚Äôt give a ETA. in any case, tt-rss apk updates very rarely so it‚Äôs not a big deal.
as a workaround, you can subscribe to the project RSS feed, if there‚Äôs a new master commit = there‚Äôs a new release.
articles.title: F-Droid repository for tt-rss

articles.author: @webracer999
articles.description:
For me: I would be happy, if there‚Äôs a f-droid repo. But - I got your point above and I‚Äôm not the person who has to maintain the repo.
I don‚Äôt understand what the gitlab CI changes (sorry, I‚Äôm technically not really on this topic) beside the app internal updater.
If I have two wishes, they would be: 
Delete the f-droid repo, if you don‚Äôt maintain it in the future - so it‚Äôs clear for the user
What do I have to ‚Äúmigrate‚Äù to the ‚Äúnew‚Äù update method? Do I have to reinstall the app etc.?
articles.title: F-Droid repository for tt-rss

articles.author: @fox
articles.description:
to give a concrete example on how this could work:
https://gitlab.tt-rss.org/main/the-epube-android/-/pipelines/161
above pipeline builds an APK and creates a project release visible here
https://gitlab.tt-rss.org/main/the-epube-android
which leads to here
https://gitlab.tt-rss.org/main/the-epube-android/-/releases
where there‚Äôs an APK link
the whole thing is built using a dead simple CI template (https://gitlab.tt-rss.org/ci/ci-templates/-/blob/master/.ci-build-apk-fdroid.yml) which is about as straightforward as you can get.
this is how this should work. screw stupid bespoke repos and screw f-droid in particular.
articles.title: F-Droid repository for tt-rss

articles.author: @fox
articles.description:
now that i think about it, i‚Äôm using gitlab already anyway so it would make sense to use gitlab CI for build artifacts (in this case, APKs) instead of doing this song-and-dance copying the file somewhere for no particular reason.
i.e. https://gitlab.tt-rss.org/tt-rss/tt-rss-android/-/jobs/65/artifacts/browse/org.fox.ttrss/build/outputs/apk/fdroid/ etc
to make it a bit easier to figure out CI could generate a release linking to the artifact.
articles.title: F-Droid repository for tt-rss

articles.author: @fox
articles.description:
webracer999:
Is it possible that you update to a newer version of fdroidserver?
that entirely depends on how backwards-compatible the newer version is. do they have a migration guide or something? idk.

 webracer999:
will fix the crash, but users won‚Äôt be able to update the apps without SHA256 signer,
well it won‚Äôt crash but without updating the apps it makes the whole thing useless then.
honestly i‚Äôm not sure if the repo is even needed. all apks have built-in update notifications anyway. it might be easier to just keep those with direct downloads and remove the fdroid thing altogether. it feels like an unnecessary kludge.
e: it would be a lot easier for my CI processes anyway if i won‚Äôt have to invoke their super-slow docker-based repo builder.
the whole ‚Äúwe‚Äôre not going to allow you to install the apps because of some imaginary security circus-tier scenario we‚Äôve imagined where someone goes for a repo signature collision (i guess) which would also involve an SSL MITM and somehow bypass APK signature afterwards‚Äù doesn‚Äôt fill me with desire to deal with any of this at all.
articles.title: F-Droid repository for tt-rss

articles.author: @webracer999
articles.description:
Yes, Foxy Droid works and is a workaround for me.
Meanwhile F-Droid team has written:
this repo is created with a very old version of fdroidserver which publishes signature information with MD5 still. Is there any way the repo owner could update to a newer version?
Don't crash when app has no signer at all (!1217) ¬∑ Merge requests ¬∑ F-Droid / Client ¬∑ GitLab will fix the crash, but users won‚Äôt be able to update the apps without SHA256 signer, because fdroidclient doesn‚Äôt support the old MD5 sig anymore, so it considers the signatures to be incompatible.
App details: java.lang.NullPointerException (#2598) ¬∑ Issues ¬∑ F-Droid / Client ¬∑ GitLab)
So I think that‚Äôs the point, why Foxy Droid still works.
articles.title: F-Droid repository for tt-rss

articles.author: @webracer999
articles.description:
OK, f-droid crashes, but I think there is a signature problem in the repo.
https://srv.tt-rss.org/fdroid/repo/index-v1.jar
keytool -printcert -file META-INF/977ADA9E.RSA
outputs:
SHA256: C1:17:B9:EA:ED:FC:BA:8B:EF:73:26:3C:A9:49:0D:B9:05:ED:FF:FE:5D:7C:07:1F:FA:AE:15:2A:75:FC:B6:E4
This footprint is also displayed in f-droid repo details:


https://srv.tt-rss.org/fdroid/repo/org.fox.ttrss-fdroid.apk
apksigner verify --print-certs org.fox.ttrss-fdroid.apk
outputs:

articles.author: @ekalin Eduardo Kalinowski
articles.description:
geo5ukr:
To give an example:
This should find any decimal lat/long in articles, f.i. 46.167314, 34.811968 should match this.
You‚Äôre anchoring the regexp at the beginning (^) and end ($). This means it will match coordinates, but only if there is nothing else around the coordinates.
I don‚Äôt know what string is passed by tt-rss when matching, it it‚Äôs the whole text or line by line. (And some regexp libraries treat ^ and $ as beginning and end of a line in multi-line texts), but even in the best scenario (line by line), it would only match if a line consisted only the the coordinates.
So try without the ^ and $.

articles.author: @fox
articles.description:
it should work the same, the only difference is that tt-rss source is not pulled from git. however, i would instead try to map themes.local & plugins.local instead of tt-rss/ so that main tt-rss source is guaranteed to update properly. it‚Äôs easy to screw up permissions on bind mounts. not sure if it‚Äôll work or not.
something like this
# docker-compose.override.yml

version: '3'

services:
  app:
    volumes:
      - ./tt-rss/plugins.local:/var/www/html/tt-rss/plugins.local
      - ./tt-rss/themes.local:/var/www/html/tt-rss/themes.local

  updater:
    volumes:
      - ./tt-rss/plugins.local:/var/www/html/tt-rss/plugins.local
      - ./tt-rss/themes.local:/var/www/html/tt-rss/themes.local

  web-nginx:
    volumes:
      - ./tt-rss/plugins.local:/var/www/html/tt-rss/plugins.local
      - ./tt-rss/themes.local:/var/www/html/tt-rss/themes.local

if this works properly, i‚Äôll update the faq entry on how to have custom plugins and stuff.

Well crap, it sure looks like the fault is mine. I have been using using a docker-compose.override.yml in order to configure volumes so I can add my own themes and plugins as well as the local-overrides.js file for the Safari fix (plus some minor development in the past but it has been a long time.) I was using the dynamic build instructions from the Docker FAQ.
What is the recommended procedure for installing custom themes/scripts if using static-dockerhub? The Docker FAQ mentions modifying docker-compose.yml changing (I assume):
    volumes:
      - app:/var/www/html
      - ./config.d:/opt/tt-rss/config.d:ro

to
    volumes:
      - /opt/tt-rss:/var/www/html
      - ./config.d:/opt/tt-rss/config.d:ro

Sorry, but I really am still a Docker newbie, just trying to tread lightly so I don‚Äôt run into the same issues converting from dynamic to static as some other folks.

tsimmons:
My origin URL is https://git.tt-rss.org/fox/ttrss-docker-compose.git ‚Ä¶ Am I‚Äôm doing something wrong?
unless you‚Äôre a developer, you should use pre-baked docker images:
https://git.tt-rss.org/fox/ttrss-docker-compose.git/tree/README.md?h=static-dockerhub
basically just replace the compose file from static-dockerhub branch (above) in the same directory so it would pull images instead of trying to build your own.
alternatively, pull latest docker scripts and investigate why latest source is not pulled while building.
but seriously, just use docker hub images. there‚Äôs no need to use anything else now that they‚Äôre multiplatform.

articles.author: @extra808
articles.description:
Tiny Tiny RSS needs window.requestIdleCallback but it‚Äôs not supported in Safari. You used to be able to enable it by turning on the ‚ÄúrequestIdleCallback‚Äù flag under ‚ÄúExperimental Features‚Äù but as of version 16.4.1 (Mac and mobile Safari), that option is gone. It‚Äôs also gone from Safari Technology Preview.
To use Safari (or any browser on iOS/iPadOS), follow the advice given before:
Create themes-local/local-overrides.js
Put the contents of https://github.com/pladaria/requestidlecallback-polyfill/blob/master/index.js  there.
